MINUTE OF THE INTERNATIONAL HEALTH BOARD
REGARDING DR. HENRY ROSE CARTER

The death of Dr. Henry Rose Carter, assistant surgeon-general
of the United States Public Health Service, at his home in Washington on
September 14, 1925, in the seventy-fourth year of his age, was reported to
the Board at the meeting immediately following his death and was the oc-
casion of an appreciative memorial sketch of his life and work in the Bul-
letin of the International Health Board of October, 1925. Dr. Carter's
relations to the Board during the last decade of his life as a member of
its Yellow Fever Commission headed by General Gorgas, and since 1920, of
the succeeding Yellow Fever Council, and as the author of the forthcoming
History of Yellow Fever, the preparation and publication of which have
been made possible by aid from the Board, were so important and so highly
esteemed, that a minute commemorating his services should find a place in
its permanent records.

Dr. Carter, born in Virginia and his life largely spent in the
South, was trained in civil engineering, mathematics and the classics at
the University of Virginia. His natural endowment of an unusually clear,
logical, analytic type of mind was further strengthened by three years of
teaching of mathematics, the last one being at his alma mater. Diverted
by an accident from the career of a civil engineer, he was graduated in
medicine in 1879 at the University of Maryland and at once entered the Ma-
rine Hospital Service now the United States Public Health Service, a con-
nection which determined for the remainder of his life the direction and
range of his professional interests, studies and work.

He showed marked aptitude and ability for clinical work during
the early years spent mainly in the hospitals of the Service, but his
great opportunity came with his detail in 1888 to the federal quarantine
station on Ship Island off Biloxi, Mississippi. Much space would be re-
quired to set forth adequately and correctly Carter's personal share in
the reform of maritime quarantine principles and practice in the United
States. Here it must suffice to state that his achievements in this field
are widely recognized and that the improvements which he introduced rank
among his major services and were largely instrumental, through the confi-
dence which he inspired, in securing the transfer of local city and state
quarantine stations to the federal government, thereby placing the system
upon a sound and unified basis.

The position which he had attained as an authority and efficient
administrator of maritime quarantine is evidenced by his detail in 1898 to
organize the quarantine service of Cuba, the most difficult and important
assignment in this line of duty which existed at that time, and not less
important, his appointment in 1904 to a similar post in the Panama Canal
Zone, where from 1905 to 1909 he was director of hospitals and second only
to General Gorgas in authority in the sanitary department and probably also
in the practical work of sanitation on the Isthmus. Certainly the associa-
tion between Gorgas and Carter then and later was of the most intimate per-
sonal and friendly character.

Carter's work on yellow fever and on malaria, particularly the
former, entitles him to rank among the leading epidemiologists of his gen-
eration. It is safe to say that no more acute, brilliant and able epidemi-
ological study based solely upon the observation and interpretation of na-
3.
ture's confusing experiments in the production and spread of epidemic di-
sease, without the aid of human or animal experimentation under controlled
conditions, has been made since John Snow's study of cholera and William
Budd's of typhoid fever over sixty years ago than Carter's investigations
of the intrinsic and extrinsic incubation of yellow fever. Among the con-
siderations which determined the direction of Walter Reed's and his co-
workers' work in the search for an intermediate host in yellow fever, Reed
himself assigned the first importance to these observations of Carter.

The peculiar quality of excellence attaching to all of Carter's
work continued to be manifested in his studies and efforts at control of
malaria dating from 1913 and continuing throughout the period of the world
war, during our participation in which he assumed with striking success
particularly arduous duties in the anti-malarial control of the zones
around army cantonments. Although the basic principles of control were
already established, Carter showed great acumen in noting the existence of
many local problems, such as the role of impounded waters, upon the solution
of which practical success depended. He clearly recognized in studying the
situation in our Southern States that there can be no general program of
malaria control of universal applicability and that the problems of each
locality must be separately studied, a direction of investigation still
further elaborated and pursued by workers of the International Health Board.

While Dr. Carter was interested and widely informed in the whole
field of public health and epidemiology, and in addition both within the pro-
fession and outside it, was a cultured scholar, his published contributions
about thirty in number, were limited to a narrow range of subjects, and these
related chiefly to problems presented in the line of his official duties in
4.
the administrative control of epidemic diseases. Dr. Carter is a rare and
outstanding example of a man vigorous in action and charged with responsi-
bilities of high importance who applies to the successful solution of the
problems which he faces those qualities of the enquiring mind, those meth-
ods of investigation and that precision of judgment in weighing evidence
which characterize the scientific investigator and are rarely combined
with efficiency in administration.

Carter's success in securing the confidence and cordial support
so necessary to his work, of commercial bodies, teachers, officials, and the
public in general by quiet but impressive methods, avoiding over-statement
and exaggeration, may well be studied in these days of the conventional and
sometimes sensational health propagandist. Fundamentally, it was the rare
personality of this gentle, wise, restrained and thoughtful man with com-
plete mastery of his subject and with a rich background of experience which
at once inspired the confidence and secured the support of those to whom he
appealed. These, too, were the qualities which secured the singular loyalty,
attachment and affection of his associates, especially of the young men so
fortunate as to be trained by Carter in malaria and yellow fever work.

Dr. Carter's authority and well-supported opinions, with those of
his colleagues, carried great weight in deciding the International Health
Board to initiate the campaign for the complete eradication of yellow fever.
He was associated with this undertaking from its inception. His judgment in
determining the points of attack and in planning and executing the measures
adopted have been of incalculable value. It is a source of great gratifica-
tion to the Board to have been able to enlist Dr. Carter for the preparation
of the work on the History of Yellow Fever, to which the last three years of
5.
his life, in spite of physical disabilities, were ardently devoted. It is
believed that the publication of this work, the most important part of which
was left practically completed, will be an enduring monument to the ability,
scholarship and powers of reasoning of Dr. Carter.

The International Health Board by this minute records its grate-
ful appreciation of the invaluable services of Dr. Carter and its profound
sense of loss to the Board as well as to science and preventive medicine
by his death.

Presented to the Board by its Committee
consisting of Dr. William H. Welch, Dr. David L.
Edsall, and Dr. Simon Flexner, and adopted by a
rising vote at the meeting on November 4, 1926.
